content.question: Which of the following pairs of diagrams represents the change with the greatest positive value of <math alttext="delta s naught" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msup><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>∘</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>?

choices.label: The figure shows a pair of particle diagrams. An arrow extends from the first diagram to the second. The first particle diagram shows six shaded particles and six unshaded particles. The shaded particles are tightly packed in two rows and three columns in the lower left part of the diagram. The unshaded particles are in three pairs of two, scattered throughout the diagram. The second particle diagram shows all twelve particles tightly packed in two rows and six columns, alternating between shaded and unshaded.

The figure shows a pair of particle diagrams. An arrow extends from the first diagram to the second. The first particle diagram shows all twelve particles tightly packed in two rows and six columns, alternating between shaded and unshaded. The second particle diagram shows six shaded particles and six unshaded particles. The shaded particles are tightly packed in two rows and three columns in the lower left part of the diagram. The unshaded particles are in three pairs of two, scattered throughout the diagram.

The figure shows a pair of particle diagrams. An arrow extends from the first diagram to the second. The first particle diagram shows six unshaded particles tightly packed in two rows and three columns in the lower left part of the diagram. The second particle diagram shows six unshaded particles scattered throughout the diagram.

The figure shows a pair of particle diagrams. An arrow extends from the first diagram to the second. The first particle diagram shows six pairs of particles scattered throughout the diagram. Each pair has one shaded particle and one unshaded particle. The second particle diagram shows six pairs of particles scattered throughout the diagram. Three pairs are comprised of shaded particles and three pairs are comprised of unshaded particles.

content.answer: The figure shows a pair of particle diagrams. An arrow extends from the first diagram to the second. The first particle diagram shows six unshaded particles tightly packed in two rows and three columns in the lower left part of the diagram. The second particle diagram shows six unshaded particles scattered throughout the diagram.

skill.text: 4.A: Predict and/or explain chemical properties or phenomena (e.g., of atoms or molecules) using given chemical theories, models, and representations.
